bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cornelia Knox Kean, September 5, 1950

div1.p: Hench writes about how much Jefferson Randolph Kean meant to him and how he combined dignity, scholarship, and integrity.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Cornelia Knox Kean, September 5, 1950

opener.dateline:
September 5, 1950 Mrs. J. R. Kean
2804 N Street, N. W.
Georgetown
Washington 7, D. C.

div1.p:
I was greatly distressed to have the note from Robert that his father
was not well. I was consumed with the desire to get in touch with his physician
at Walter Reed. I discused General Kean's problem with our urologists and was
in the mood to suggest that he come here; then I realized that everything was
being done for him that could be done and that he was in no condition to come
here. I also did not want to let my anxious interest in General Kean be con-
strued as meddlesome interference. Therefore I refrained and did nothing.
This morning's telegram from Colonel Silor has grieved me greatly.

It has been one of the rare and richest experiences of my life to
have known General Kean so intimately as he has been like a father to me and
as I stated in my wire, I have gotten a tremendous stimulation and inspira-
tion from him. He was one of the finest gentlemen I ever know. I shall hold
him in reverent memory always. I shall never forget his voice, his chuckle,
his graciousness, his utter devotion to the truth, his scholarly attainments.
Many a time at 5 o'clock in the afternoon I think of him quietly taking his
afternoon libation and I have often wished I could sit and watch him enjoy
it. When I was there he performed this ritual with such a quaint dignity,
as if he were silently toasting comrades of the past as well as loved ones
and friends of the present.

This generation unfortunately, it seems to me, does not often produce
the combination of dignity, scholarship integrity and worth such as he rep-
resented. He was indeed a “gentleman of the old school.” Just the other
evening I got out about forty letters which he had given me a couple of years
ago, letters written by him from Cuba to, I believe, his mother-in-law. Such
gracious letters they were. Indeed I was planning to have them all typed in
sequence so that his son and you should have a copy. I should love to keep
the letters but if you wish them a copy will suffice for me and I can send
the originals to you or Robert. The letters were some of those which he
found a couple of years ago in a cellar trunk and he sent me or let me take
those which had any reference to yellow fever.

We are not left without him. We have wonderful memories which
are rich and vital. Mary joins me in sending you our deepest sympathy
and affectionate regards.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
